content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The slide displays multiple sections of tissue, most of which have the characteristic nodular and basophilic appearance of lymph nodes. I can identify approximately 6-7 lymph nodes of varying sizes, embedded in what appears to be adipose and connective tissue. The overall architecture of the nodes seems largely preserved from this low magnification, but a detailed examination is necessary to rule out micrometastases.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, I would examine each lymph node systematically to look for evidence of metastasis. The green box is placed on the first lymph node from the top left, which is a logical starting point for a methodical review. I am zooming in to assess the capsule, the subcapsular sinus, and the parenchyma of the node for any atypical cell clusters that would indicate the presence of metastatic tumor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area because it is located at the periphery of a lymph node (the fourth one from the top, on the left). When examining lymph nodes for metastatic cancer, it is critical to carefully inspect the entire capsule and the subcapsular sinus, as this is the most common initial site for tumor cells to deposit after arriving via afferent lymphatic vessels. This particular zoom allows for a high-magnification assessment of the interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding perinodal adipose tissue. The goal is to search for any atypical epithelial cells, either in clusters or as single cells, which would indicate metastasis, and to assess for any breach of the capsule (extranodal extension). I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. When examining lymph nodes for a cancer case, the main goal is to identify metastasis. At low power, I screen for any disruption of the normal lymph node architecture (cortex, paracortex, germinal centers). The lymph node targeted by the green box (the third large node from the top left) shows a clear demarcation between what appears to be normal lymphoid tissue on the right and a paler, more disorganized area on the left. This sharp interface is highly suspicious for an infiltration by a non-lymphoid cell population, such as a metastatic tumor. I am zooming in to examine the cellular morphology at this junction to confirm if it represents metastatic adenocarcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the second lymph node from the top on the left side. At low power, this node shows a clear architectural abnormality. Unlike a normal or reactive lymph node with a uniform dark purple appearance, this area has a mottled look with pale, pinkish regions disrupting the normal lymphoid tissue. This appearance is highly suspicious for metastatic carcinoma replacing the native lymphocytes, and high-power examination is necessary to confirm the presence of malignant cells. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area because it represents one of the smaller lymph nodes on the slide (the 5th distinct node from the top). It is standard practice to examine every single lymph node, regardless of size, to determine the final N-stage. I need to assess its architecture at high power to rule out micrometastasis or isolated tumor cells which might not be apparent at low magnification. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I would zoom into this area, which is located on the largest, most centrally placed lymph node, because its appearance at low power is highly suspicious. The node shows a uniform, dark purple coloration, lacking the typical follicular architecture of a reactive or normal lymph node. This pattern of total effacement is a strong indicator of a significant pathological process, most likely a massive infiltration by tumor cells. Examining this area at high power is crucial to identify the nature of the infiltrating cells and confirm or rule out metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this specific area, which is the largest lymph node on the right, because at low magnification it displays a classic feature of metastasis. There is a large, pale, eosinophilic region expanding and effacing the normal lymphoid architecture. This suggests replacement of the normal lymphocytes by a non-lymphoid, likely malignant, cell population. The goal is to examine this suspicious area at high power to confirm the presence of tumor cells and make a definitive diagnosis of a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining each lymph node. This specific zoom is on the third lymph node from the top, a large, well-circumscribed node on the right. I am zooming into the periphery of the node to carefully inspect the capsule and the subcapsular sinus. The subcapsular sinus is the first place metastatic cells typically arrive and implant within a lymph node, so it is a high-yield area to screen for early metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am examining the smallest lymph node located on the far right of the slide. Pathological review requires a systematic examination of all lymph nodes present. I am zooming into the periphery of this node, specifically the subcapsular region and the interface with the surrounding fatty tissue. This area is critical because the subcapsular sinus is often the first site of metastatic deposits. Any irregularity in the capsule or the presence of atypical cells in this location is highly suspicious for metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see the normal architecture of the lymph node is being infiltrated. There is a background population of small, dark lymphocytes. However, scattered throughout are conspicuous clusters and nests of large, atypical cells. These cells have abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, large pleomorphic nuclei with irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. These features are characteristic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node containing metastatic carcinoma, consistent with an origin from a colorectal primary.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see two distinct tissue types. The upper portion consists of dense lymphoid tissue, composed of a packed population of small, round lymphocytes with dark nuclei and scant cytoplasm. There are some scattered larger lymphoid cells, which may be part of a reactive process. The lower portion is mature adipose tissue, characterized by large, empty-appearing adipocytes. A thin, fibrous lymph node capsule clearly separates the lymphoid parenchyma from the surrounding fat. I do not see any atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant cells, or single infiltrative tumor cells in the subcapsular sinus or invading the adipose tissue. My impression of this specific field is that it shows a benign/reactive lymph node with an intact capsule and no evidence of metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there is a stark contrast between two cell populations. On the right and extending to the top, there is a dense, monotonous sheet of small, dark lymphocytes, which is the native lymph node tissue. On the left and bottom, there is an infiltrate of malignant cells arranged in irregular, back-to-back glands and nests. These tumor cells are much larger than the lymphocytes, with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, pleomorphic nuclei, and prominent nucleoli. The glandular formation is a key feature of adenocarcinoma. My impression is definitive for metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating the lymph node. This is a positive lymph node. The black lines are likely pen marks or sectioning artifacts.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In the zoomed-in area, the normal architecture of the lymph node is effaced and replaced by infiltrating nests and sheets of malignant cells. These cells are much larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, with abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large pleomorphic nuclei, irregular nuclear contours, and prominent nucleoli. They are forming poorly-differentiated glandular and cribriform structures. There is also associated necrosis and cellular debris. My impression is unequivocal metastatic adenocarcinoma, confirming this is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in view, I see a portion of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The lymphoid tissue is composed of a dense population of lymphocytes, and the overall architecture appears preserved. I do not see any atypical cell clusters, glandular structures, or significant necrosis that would indicate the presence of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The dark, linear markings are sectioning artifacts (e.g., knife marks or folds). My impression of this specific area is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the normal lymphoid tissue is largely replaced by a dense infiltrate. I can clearly distinguish two cell populations: a background of small, dark lymphocytes and conspicuous clusters of large, atypical epithelial cells. These atypical cells have abundant eosinophilic cytoplasm, large pleomorphic nuclei with irregular contours, and vesicular chromatin. Some are forming poorly defined glandular structures. This morphology is diagnostic of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node, containing metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, there is a clear demarcation between two distinct cell populations. On the lower left, there is a dense sheet of small, dark, round cells with scant cytoplasm, which are residual lymphocytes of the lymph node. The rest of the field is infiltrated by malignant cells. These cells are much larger, with abundant eosinophilic (pink) cytoplasm, and large, pleomorphic, vesicular nuclei with prominent nucleoli. They are arranged in poorly formed, back-to-back glandular structures and irregular clusters, which is characteristic of adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is metastatic adenocarcinoma infiltrating a lymph node, confirming this node as positive for malignancy.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the edge of the lymph node. On the left is pericapsular adipose tissue. On the right is the dense lymphoid tissue. Crucially, the subcapsular sinus, the space just under the capsule, is expanded and filled with clusters of non-lymphoid, atypical cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic cytoplasm, and pleomorphic nuclei. This finding is diagnostic of metastatic carcinoma infiltrating the subcapsular sinus. This is a positive lymph node.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in image shows the edge of the lymph node (right) adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue (left). Within the subcapsular sinus and extending through the capsule into the surrounding fat, there are nests and clusters of atypical epithelial cells. These cells are larger than the surrounding lymphocytes, have more eosinophilic cytoplasm, pleomorphic nuclei, and appear to form abortive glandular structures. This morphology is consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a positive lymph node with extranodal extension of the tumor.
